Introduction

Inspections are a key tool to monitor and improve quality, benchmarking to identify and address issues and provide assurance and evidence of effective control. Historically we collected audit data manually with paper audits. The manual inspection process was deemed to be time consuming and issues raised were not always addressed in a timely manner. As a Trust we are introducing Perfect ward as a tool, which will provide real time automated reporting, enabling the Trust to see at a glance the priorities needed to be addressed and to track and evidence performance across the Trust.
Productivity saving through quicker reviews and elimination of administration
Improved quality review process: quicker resolution of issues
Standardised view of quality and safety outcomes
Increased staff engagement
Continuous quality improvement
Improved assurance.
The data can be pulled into a dashboard
Scope
The purpose of this document is to implement the Perfect ward system. Perfect ward is an audit and quality improvement tool to improve the quality of care we deliver for our patients.
Perfect ward quality /and safety review process

Each clinical area is required to be assessed daily by a Ward manager (or designated band 6). Other members of the team can participate in the audits but the Ward Manager is overall responsible. The assessor must carry out the daily audits in the morning. Weekly audits need to be completed by 5PM on a Friday. Monthly Audits must be completed by the 26th of each month.

Each clinical area has a Matron identified to ensure that the audits and action plans are completed and to monitor ward compliance. The Matrons have a responsibility for ensuring all perfect ward audits take place and finding assessor cover when this is required. The Matron will participate in inspection audits when follow up audits are required as specified below:
Areas scoring above 80% will be rated as green.
Areas scoring less than  % but more than 70 % will be rated as amber.
Areas scoring less than  % will be rated as red.
Any clinical area scoring less than 80% in their audit should complete a Perfect ward improvement plan to address the issues identified.
The action plan should be led by the Matron for the clinical area, but produced alongside the ward leads.
Wards scoring less than  % should look to take immediate action to correct identified issues. When issues have been corrected, the ward manager/ Matron should reassess the area.
Wards scoring under 70% (a red score) will require re- Audit by the Matron assessor within a two week period. The Matron should contact the ward manager to agree a suitable time for re-audit.
The matrons are responsible for ensuring they plan regular walk rounds to support improved leadership presence and drive quality.
If during the audit repeat concerns need addressing an improvement plan should also be produced. The Matron is responsible ensuring the improvement plans are current.
Wards scoring above 90% on three consecutive occasions will be required to be audited by the Matron within a two week time frame.
Perfect ward audit result's should be monitored and acted upon as required at divisional level, through clinical governance meetings , and presented by a ward delegate.
For wards scoring under 70 % (a red score), the assessor will need to notify the Matron/ Associate director of nursing to arrange a repeat inspection.

Roles and Responsibilities
Ward assessor
4.1.1 Undertake quality review audit allocated daily, weekly and monthly as per audit requirements.
4.1.2 Security and care of allocated I Pad device.
4.1.3 Notify ward manager and Matron when an action plan is required.
4.1.4 Notify Matron Assessor when a re-audit is required
Matron assessor
4.2.1 Ensure all allocated clinical areas have assessors identified and that all quality review takes place. On occasion this will involve identifying alternative assessors.
4.2.2 Undertake follow up audits as required.
4.2.3 Ensure audits are completed as required.
Associate Director of Nursing
4.3.1 To ensure all issues and improvement plans identified from Perfect ward quality reviews in the division are addressed and completed.
4.3.2 To notify Divisional director of nursing any red score audits within the division, with detailed improvement plans and re-auditing schedule.
4.3.3 To ensure Perfect ward results are discussed at divisional governance meetings.
Pharmacy
4.4.1 Pharmacy staff undertaken medicines optimisation audits at quarterly/4-monthly cycles depending on audit (controlled drugs, safe and secure storage, FP10s, omissions)
4.4.2 Ensure audits are feedback via a pre-populated action plan to ward manger and matron in timely manner post audit
4.4.3 Guidance and support provided via the Medication Safety Team on request and directly where a red RAG audit result is recorded.
4.4.4 Results are tabled at site Medicines Optimisation & Safety Group (MOSG) monthly to track and promote learning
Technical requirements and support
4.5.1 The app will be installed on Trust – provided and profiled mobile devices.
4.5.2 New users will need to set up alert notifications on the app through the settings tool. Auto logout should be enabled and set for two hours,
4.5.3 Devices will be supported by the Trust IT support. Issues to be reported to IT helpdesk or via the self-service portal.
4.5.4 Password problems or new users requiring registration should be reported to Perfect lead project lead who will liaise with the company.
Perfect ward reports
4.6.1 The perfect ward App generates individual ward reports and Monthly Trust wide organisation reports.
4.6.2 These will be accessible through the Perfect ward APP.

4.6.3 Ward reports should be reviewed each month by the ward manager and matron for the area. Low scoring and wards identifying repeat issues will require the development of action plans. Low scoring reports and action plans should be shared at the divisional governance forums. Discussions with the ward and Matrons to identify areas that need increased support and if required training.
4.6.4 Reports should be printed out and displayed for staff, patients and visitors.
4.6.5 Results and improvement plans to be discussed at ward meetings and available visible for all staff to see.
Information governance considerations
4.7.1 No person's confidential data should be captured via the perfect ward application during quality reviews/Audit.

4.7.2 All images should be clear of identifiable information in any format. This would include images of written information such as Patients notes, handover sheets, patient boards, staff rosters etc.
4.7.3 Images should be clear from physical identification such as pictures of an individual which identifies them i.e. / facial features, distinguishable markings etc.
Responsibilities and accountability
4.8.1  Ward managers and Matrons will be responsible for undertaking of quality reviews and should therefore ensure they comply with the information Governance standards above.
Reporting Person Confidential Data (PCD) breaches

4.9.1 In the event that PCD is captured during an audit the ward manger is responsible for ensuring the incident is reported as a confidential breech via the Datix system and escalating to the limber manager.

4.9.2 Matrons are responsible for revising all weekly audits and being vigilant for any PCD information in any photographs. If found, they will need to email Perfect Ward on info@perfectward.com t have the whole audit deleted, this audit will then need to be repeated.
4.9.3 The Matron will follow up with the individual to discuss IG and the ramifications of a confidentiality breach.
Training requirements
4.10.1 Perfect ward has been designed to have minimal training requirements. Assessors will be provided with a user guide.
4.10.2 There will also be a training video accessible via the I learn system.
4.10.3 To support assessors, each question within the Perfect ward App has guidance notes to help direct the assessor as to the required standard for the specific question.
4.10.4 As a Trust we will be supporting train the trainer super user training, ideally there will be a super user identified for each area.
4.10.5 Ongoing training for new assessors will be provided by experienced users.
4.10.6 Additional training on troubleshooting and how to get the most out of reports functionality can be provided by the Perfect ward Trust lead.
Operational Leadership
Matrons will be responsible for ensuring audits are undertaken and when required allocating new assessors to clinical areas. This will be overseen by the Divisional directors of nursing/ Midwifery.

Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the quality work stream group which is the specialist group with the authority to approve Perfect ward guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the quality work stream group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
